The data is stored in JSON files.
Assets are stored alongside the content.
These files can be managed in git.

div.font:
Multiple TachyonCMS services are provided for accessing the files.
The Desktop Editor, Storage API and Amplify App allow editing the data,
the Flow Server provides high-performance read-only access.

div.span:
The Quasar framework allows generating multiple clients from the same code base.
The Desktop Editor will be the first production ready client, followed by the web app.
The native Android and iOS clients will be worked on after the other pieces are in production.

div.font: A key goal of TachyonCMS was being able to implement a git-based workflow around the data, as was being able to easily access the data in emergencies. Storing the data in simple JSON files with the assets collocated right alongside achieves both of those goals.

switch.text: A key goal of TachyonCMS was being able to implement a git-based workflow around...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 599px; height: 1px; padding-top: 350px; margin-left: 50px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 14px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 678px; height: 1px; padding-top: 389px; margin-left: 12px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 14px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

li.span: Low or NO cost. The Desktop Editor with a free GitHub account and a free static hosting provide a FREE CMS. The only cost would be if you get enough traffic the "free" static hosting providers will eventually charge something.
ALL previous versions are stored, versus possibly none in other CMS.
You can revert a single object, or the entire catalog to any previous version. Compared to updating
li.font: each object separately in many CMS.

li.span: You can create multiple optional change sets, which can be quickly released. This would be useful if you were sponsoring an athlete and wanted to have various sets of content ready for release depending upon how the athlete places. Most CMS are limited to dealing with one upcoming change set, if any.
A diff provides a clear understanding of a content changes, much better than just proofing the new copy to see if it looks "ok".

Easily integrate content updates with code updates. Most code deploy processes use git somewhere in the process, adding an additional "git pull" is easier than making what could be multiple API calls to a CMS.
A huge existing base of people already familiar with git processes. Every developer and many non-developers have used git to checkout code.
The simple format means data can be viewed and edited by a lowly text editor, this can be important in emergency situations.

Extensibility. Most CMS, and in fact most products in general vehemently recommend against having other systems update the data they manage. The TachyonCMS JSON files are meant to be modified by other processes.

switch.text: Low or NO cost. The Desktop Editor with a free GitHub account and a free static hosting provide a...

div.div:
The Desktop Editor is the Quasar application built as an Electron app.
It implements the Storage API directly so no other service is needed.
This provides a CMS editor that is not only serverless, but cloudless and independent of network access.
You can run as many copies of the editor as you want, and you can
manage as many Flows as you want. All for free.
A future version will support connecting to a remote Storage API or Amplify API. You will be able to toggle between the various sources and use the same editor no matter where the data is stored. This will facilitate moving data between the various sources as well.

switch.text: The Desktop Editor is the Quasar application built as an Electron app....

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1187px; margin-left: 1189px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 18px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: nowrap;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 118px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1239px; margin-left: 1381px;

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 428px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1230px; margin-left: 912px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 16px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The Storage API is a Node application that allows either the web or Electron app to read and write data on remote servers.
The primary use is running it locally and connecting to from a mobile device using either the web app or the native client. The enables capturing new content using the fancy cameras and microphones built into modern mobile devices.
The captured images, video or audio are streamed directly to the Storage API without being stored on the local device. This allows a storage limited device to capture terabytes of data.
The captured content is stored directly inside a Nugget directory, right alongside the content. This creates an easily portable "nugget" of information.

switch.text: The Storage API is a Node application that allows eith...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1687px; margin-left: 1188px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 18px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: nowrap;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 427px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1730px; margin-left: 912px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 16px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The Amplify API will provide an AppSync API interface that stored the data in AWS. We will support both S3 and DynamoDB storage as they have different use-cases.
Amplify apps have low fixed costs, only those associated with the data storage. There isn't any "reserved hardware" you are paying for.
The S3 version will include S3 Lambda that allow more complex fetches in a single GET request. Keeping with the AWS recommendation that you should try and design your data so that only one network request is needed.
The app will support a single tenant, though you can run as many instances as you want for free. The single tenant version will be a the basis for a future SaaS version.

switch.text: The Amplify API will provide an AppSync API interface...

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 16px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The Flow Server provides static CMS content. It exposes the raw JSON files to consumer apps. By putting a quality CDN in front of the Flow Server you scale to any level effortlessly and for pennies compared to any CMS relying on dedicated compute resources.
The flow server is a partially compiled static site. A lightweight web app is compiled to serve the raw JSON as formatted web pages. A client app can request various properties of flows or nuggets, or the entire data for each. The client app references those by ID like other document databases. Those client performs a GET request for the corresponding JSON file.
A stripped down version of the Web App is deployed with the JSON files. It renders the data JSON using the same renderers as the full app.
The important part to note is that the JSON data can be added or updated without redeploying the web app. The same static web app pages can automatically service new data without any updates. It does not pre-compile the HTML for each change that comes in.
We do this because we want to support a lot of data as inexpensively as possible. We want to let the client app do as much of the compilation as possible. That loses part of the benefit of precompiled static sites.
The biggest speed gain in static sites is not needing to wait for any compute activity on the server end. The compilation time is minimal, modern reactive frameworks are recalculating your view constantly.
Serving static JSON through a compiled web app accomplishes the same, ZERO COMPUTE RESOURCES. It just forces the client to do one more trivial compilation.
While compilation is trivial on the client side it can actually add up on the server side. Build minutes, deploy minutes, compute charges, test runs, cache flushes all add to the cost of each compilation. Some of that is wasted compiling data that will never be viewed as that version.

switch.text: The Flow Server provides static CMS content. It expose...

div.div: The Desktop Editor and the Flow Server together provide a FREE static hosting solution for an unlimited amount of content. There may be costs and limits from your hosting providers, but they are zero costs associated with TachyonCMS.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 578px; height: 1px; padding-top: 607px; margin-left: 1777px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;

div.div:
The Web App in conjunction with a local Storage API allows collecting unlimited amounts of data through your mobile device, the only limit is the hard drive space you have available on the Storage Server.
The Web App can also access remote Storage and Amplify APIs. This web app will be the basis for an upcoming SaaS version.

div.div: The Android version will be the first native version, mainly because development devices are cheap and plentiful. We'll be relying on the Quasar framework to make that relatively painless.

switch.text: The Android version will be the first native version, mainly because dev...

div.div: The iOS app will come at the end, and ten only if we find an acceptable development device to do the compilation on. We need a fairly recent Mac to make the customizations needed to generate an iOS app. We have an iPad we can test the builds on.

switch.text: The iOS app will come at the end, and ten only if we find an acceptable...

a.text: Text is not SVG - cannot display
